I had asked in the past about the ability to be able to use these to set defaults for color pickers in new modules, that the marketer could then override at the page level by picking a different color from the color picker. That way the default is their color rather than a color we assign in the module. Doesn't sound like it was possible but not sure if things have changed now?
hahaha

Challenge for Ya'll :metal:
> Who can give me a 1-3 paragraph explanation of what custom modules are, why you like them, and how they compare to WordPress plugins. 
> :boom:BONUS:boom: for including helpful links 

(working on "discovery kit" for new-to-HubSpot developers)
<https://blog.wsol.com/supercharge-your-websites-functionality-with-custom-HubSpot-modules>
its older but some of the info in there should still be correct

<@U22PKFRU5> a quick description (others feel free to add/subtract as needed or build on):
```
Custom Modules allow you to expand on your HubSpot portal and create repeatable, reusable, and sometimes dynamic content to enhance your website and make it easier for content editors to build HubSpot pages in a fast and efficient way. 

They make it easier for developers to create multiple options for content editors to transform and layout their content in various ways. This means developers can focus more on the core of the module while also limiting content editors from accidentally breaking or misusing the modules for things other than their intended purposes.

These function similar to many WordPress plugins with the exception of you don’t always have to load the code for the module on every page on your site. Those who are familiar enough with HubL and its functions/filters can essentially recreate many of the most popular WordPress plugins out there. 
```
Great breakdown AJ! Thank you
Who else has their version -or- can expand on AJ's?

What really makes the HubSpot custom modules stand apart from Advanced Custom Fields is how they are instanced on the page so you can include the same module multiple times without having to create separate fieldsets for each duplicated module.
There’s a way around it in ACF but it’s a pain in my ass.
Also I’m sure <@U7SL518D6> would like to add that the HubSpot custom modules are heavily Netflix and Chilled.
I'd say HubSpot custom modules are more like making a custom shortcode in Wordpress than they are like ACF.

I use them in a pretty similar workflow to what I do in WP, where I’m writing my PHP partial and plugging in ACF output tags. Another nice thing is that they’re all in one window in HubSpot whereas in WP I have to have ACF open on one screen and Sublime in another.

My attempt at a different version though AJ’s is great:
Remember all those nights trying to find a WordPress Plugin that would mesh well with the other 15 plugins and Advanced Custom Fields plugin you have installed? What if I told you, you could get all of the same functionality, all in one cohesive way without worrying that one day - that one plugin used to insert an eggplant emojii via shortcode would kill your whole weekend due to a bad update or worse, your client’s site getting hacked. 

Introducing HubSpot Custom Modules. They’re flexible like plugins, except they have none of the problems. Use the same libraries? no big deal it can be loaded just once. Need to add fields? no problem. Need to load it 100 times on the same page and worried about code duplication? No problem. Plugin UI problems? I feel bad for you bro, plugins have 99 problems but Custom Modules not 1.

HubSpot custom modules, try them, and get back to your Netflix and Chill.

_This message not sponsored or endorsed by Netflix their subsidiaries or Chill branded beverages._
Where are you on the Ballmer Curve right now?
I’m at “Developers” x2
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ug4c2mqlE_0>

One way that we use Custom Modules is for creating re-usable content blocks for a website project.  We develop around 20 modules for a site build that act like those giant Duplo Legos your toddler drools on.  Then a marketer or client can use a Flexible column template to build out their own page by dragging in the modules they need to fit their content in whatever order that works for them. This also has the added benefit of forcing them to input content in a way that will make it harder for them to break the page (wishful thinking i know)
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wJelEXaPhJ8>
_HubSpot Modules: Like drool-proof bootleg Legos_
... that you'll never step on!

Quick Question on file manager. If I link to a file in the file manager like a zip file and I use the HubSpot CDN link `<http://cdn2.HubSpot.net/hubfs/999999/dir/item.zip|cdn2.HubSpot.net/hubfs/999999/dir/item.zip>` and then later on i update my settings on the Default File Manager Hosting Domain to use my domain as the file hosting domain, will this cause the previous link to be dead or will it redirect to the file?
